content.text: On the line below each stopwatch, state the time readings shown, in seconds. [1]
Calculate the average time interval between two drops of water hitting the ground
average time = .........s
A student measures the time interval between two drops of water hitting the ground
She uses a stopwatch and repeats the procedure three times. Fig. 1.2 shows each stopwatch reading
Another student measures the average time taken for a drop of water to fall from the tank to the ground. The time taken is 1.6s
Calculate the average speed of this drop of water
average speed = .........m/s
Fig. 1.3 shows the speed-time graph for a different drop of water
Use Fig. 1.3 to determine the distance fallen by the drop between P and Q
distance = .........m
[Total: 9]
Fig. 1.1 shows a large tank containing water. The tank leaks. Drops of water fall from the tank. The drops hit the ground at a regular rate
A student has a piece of metal that has an irregular shape. The weight of the metal is 3.0N
Calculate the mass of the metal
Describe how to determine the volume of the metal, using the equipment in Fig. 2.1
The mass of another piece of metal is \(405\mathrm{g}\) and its volume is \(150\mathrm{cm}^3\)
Calculate the density of the metal. State the unit
density = .........
[Total: 10]
Fig. 2.1 shows the piece of metal, a measuring cylinder and a beaker containing water
Describe how the devices shown in Fig. 3.1 generate electrical energy
Describe the advantages and disadvantages of generating electrical energy by using a coal-fired power station compared with the devices shown in Fig. 3.1
Fig. 3.1 shows devices that generate electricity
On Fig. 4.1, write the name of the state of matter in each of the empty boxes. [1]
On Fig. 4.1, on each unlabelled arrow, write the change of state that it represents. [1]
In Fig. 4.1, each box represents a state of matter. Each arrow shows a change of state. Some labels are missing
These statements are about particles in a liquid. Two statements are correct
Tick the boxes next to the two correct statements
The particles are in a regular pattern
The particles are as far apart as those in a gas
The particles are a similar distance apart to those in a solid
The particles vibrate about fixed positions
The particles move randomly
[Total: 4]
Fig. 5.1 shows a transverse wave. Four distances A, B, C and D are marked on the wave
State the letter that shows the amplitude of the wave
State the meaning of the term frequency of a wave
State the type of wave in the spring
State one other example of this type of wave
Use the scale in Fig. 5.2 to determine the wavelength of the wave in the spring
wavelength = .........$cm$

A long spring is fixed at one end, as shown in Fig. 5.2. The spring is moved towards and away from the fixed end, repeatedly. The compressions and rarefactions on the spring at a particular time can be seen
On Fig. 6.1, label the angle of incidence for the ray, using the letter, \(i\)
On Fig. 6.1, complete the path of the ray of green light until it hits the screen
Fig. 6.1 shows a ray of green light hitting a glass prism
The white light splits into a spectrum of colours. State the term used to describe this effect
State the colour that is refracted most by the prism
[Total: 5]
The ray of green light is replaced with a ray of white light
Healthy human ears can hear sounds in the range 2.0 Hz to 2000 Hz
Healthy human ears can hear sounds in the range 20 Hz to 20 000 Hz
Healthy human ears can hear sounds in the range 200 Hz to 200 000 Hz
Increasing the amplitude of a sound wave increases its speed
Increasing the amplitude of a sound wave increases its frequency
Increasing the amplitude of a sound wave increases its loudness
An echo is produced when sound is diffracted
An echo is produced when sound is refracted
An echo is produced when sound is reflected
[Total: 4]
Some students make statements about sound
In each part of the question, only **one** statement is correct
Place a tick in the box next to each correct statement
Sound travels at the same speed as light
Sound travels faster than the speed of light
Sound travels slower than the speed of light
On Fig. 8.1
Label the position of each pole of the magnet. Use the label N for the north pole and S for the south pole
Draw one magnetic field line above the magnet and draw one magnetic field line below the magnet
Add one arrow to show the direction of the magnetic field
State the name given to the device shown in Fig. 8.2
The student puts one end of the device in Fig. 8.2 just above a pile of iron filings
He closes the switch for a short time and then opens it again
Describe the effect this has on the iron filings
The student removes the soft iron rod and replaces it with a steel rod
He puts one end of the steel rod just above the pile of iron filings. He closes the switch for a short time and then opens it again
Describe the effect this has on the iron fillings
A student places a soft iron rod inside a coil of insulated wire. The coil is connected to a battery, as shown in Fig. 8.2
Fig. 8.1 shows a sheet of paper. A bar magnet is underneath the paper. A student sprinkles iron filings onto the paper
The current shown on ammeter \(\mathsf{A}_1\) is 0.6A
Complete the table with the values for the current that would be shown on the other two ammeters
The resistance of each lamp is \(20 \Omega\)
Determine the combined resistance of the lamps
resistance = .........$\Omega$
Compare the current from the power supply with the current in each lamp
Compare the resistance of one lamp in this circuit with the combined resistance of the two lamps connected in parallel
The circuit is changed. The two lamps are connected in parallel
A different series circuit contains a \(140\Omega\) fixed resistor. An ammeter in the circuit shows a current of 0.30A
Calculate the potential difference (p.d.) across the resistor. State the unit
Fig. 9.1 shows a circuit with two lamps and three ammeters connected in series to a power supply
State the name of the component represented by the symbol
Describe its purpose
name
purpose
State the type of electrical supply used by the cooker hood
Switch S is closed. Switch T is moved to position Y. State the name of any components that are switched on
Switch T is moved from position Y to position Z. Suggest how this change affects the motor
Fig. 10.1 shows an electrical cooker hood used in some kitchens
The cooker hood removes steam from the kitchen. It has a fan driven by a motor. It also has a lamp
Fig. 10.2 shows a simplified circuit diagram for the cooker hood
Electrical appliances with metal cases can become dangerous if there is a fault. Suggest a hazard and describe a safety feature to reduce the danger
hazard
safety feature
[Total: 7]
There is a current in the coil WXYZ. The direction of this current is shown by the arrows
On Fig. 11.1, draw an arrow to show the direction of the force acting on side WX and an arrow to show the direction of the force acting on side YZ
State three ways of increasing the turning effect of the motor
Fig. 11.1 shows a simple electric motor
In a home, a step-down transformer reduces the mains voltage of 225V to 4.5V
The transformer has 4000 turns on the primary coil
Calculate the number of turns on the secondary coil
number of turns = .........
[Total: 7]
The fuel for the power station is an isotope of uranium
Explain the meaning of the term isotope
When the nucleus of a uranium atom decays, it releases a \(\beta\) -particle
Describe the relative ionising effect, and the relative penetrating ability, of a \(\beta\) -particle
relative ionising effect
relative penetrating ability
A sample of rock includes some uranium-239
The half-life of uranium-239 is 23 minutes
Determine the fraction of the uranium-239 that remains after 46 minutes
fraction remaining = .........
[Total: 6]
A nuclear power station uses uranium to generate thermal energy
